JournalInfo.JournalSubTitle: Zeitschrift für Rohstoffe, Geotechnik, Metallurgie, Werkstoffe, Maschinen- und Anlagentechnik

ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: A Novel Devolatilization Technique of Pre-reduction of Iron Ore Using Lean Grade Coal
Neuartige Entgasungstechnik zur Vorreduktion von Eisenerz mittels minderwertiger Kohle

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Metallurgical and Material Engineering
School of Materials Science and Nano Technology

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The problem of properly utilizing non-coking coals in alternative iron making processes dates back to long ago. Lean grade coals with higher ash and volatile matter content (e.g. boiler grade coals) have always challenged the metallurgists to develop a suitable process for their utilization. The aim of this work is to achieve an energy efficient method for the reduction of briquetted iron ore fines using ‘SYNGAS’—which is the gaseous product (enriched with reducing agents) generated by pyrolysis of coal along with fine sized carbon particles produced during pyrolysis. A laboratory scale reduction furnace with pyrolysis facility has been designed and fabricated after in depth thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA), differential thermal analysis (DTA), and gas chromatograph (GC) studies. A particular temperature profile has been maintained inside the furnace to achieve the optimum reduction temperature. The briquettes are reduced in the pyrolysis furnace and the extent of reduction has been calculated from the weight loss. The reduced specimens are characterized using X-ray diffractometer (XRD), scanning electron microscope (SEM), energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX), field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM), and chemical analysis method. It is observed that iron ore can be significantly reduced to metallic iron by using the devolatilization product of lean grade coal.

Abstract.Heading: Zusammenfassung
Abstract.Para: Das Problem der richtigen Anwendung von nichtkokenden Kohlen in alternativen Eisenherstellungsverfahren ist schon lange bekannt. Minderwertige Kohlen mit höherem Aschegehalt und flüchtigen Bestandteilen (z. B. Kesselkohlen) und die Entwicklung eines geeigneten Verfahrens zu ihrer Nutzung haben schon immer die Metallurgen herausgefordert. Das Ziel dieser Arbeit ist die Entwicklung eines energieeffizienten Verfahrens zur Reduktion des brikettierten Feineisenerzes unter Verwendung von SYNGAS. SYNGAS ist das gasförmige Produkt einer Kohleentgasung, welches mit feinen Kohlepartikeln vermischt wird. Dazu wurde ein Reduktionsofen im Labormaßstab mit Entgasungsmöglichkeit nach thermo-gravimetrischen Analysen (TGA), Differentialthermoanalysen (DTA) und Gaschromatographie (GC) Untersuchungen entwickelt. Um die optimale Reduktionstemperatur zu erreichen, wird ein besonderes Temperaturprofil innerhalb des Ofens eingestellt. Die Briketts werden im Pyrolyseofen reduziert, und das Ausmaß der Reduktion wird aus dem Gewichtsverlust berechnet. Die reduzierten Proben werden unter Verwendung von Röntgen-Diffraktometrie (XRD), Rasterelektronenmikroskopie (REM), energiedispersive Röntgenspektrometer (EDX), Feldemissions-Rasterelektronenmikroskop (FE-REM) und chemischen Analyseverfahren charakterisiert. Es wurde beobachtet, dass Eisenerze durch Verwendung des Entgasungsprodukts aus minderwertigen Kohlen zu einem hohen Anteil zu metallischen Eisen reduziert werden können.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: The worldwide availability of coking coal is decreasing rapidly [1]. The steel industries are trying to incorporate non-coking coal as an alternative reductant. Non-coking coal is used to produce coal based sponge iron [2] as well as hot metal through COREX® process [3]. But in India, the quality of non-coking coal is not up to the mark because of its high ash content [4]. There is a huge reserve of lean grade coal in India [5]. So the simple technique of utilizing the volatile matter of this lower grade coal for partial reduction of iron ore through the pyrolysis of coal could be a leap forward in the iron making process. In this work, a process for pre-reduction of iron ore briquettes [6] using the volatile matter as well as the nano-sized carbon particles present in soot (produced by pyrolysis of lean grade coal) is reported. Another advantage of pre-reduction of iron ore briquettes by coal gasification [7–9] is to use the coal without direct contact between coal and iron ore, hence avoiding the chance of contamination of produced iron by coal ash. The pre-reduced briquettes [10] could be used in the blast furnace simply as a raw material, which would reduce the coke rate of the furnace significantly because of its pre-reduced character [11]. Considering energy minimization, the furnace is designed to achieve both devolatilization of coal and reduction of briquettes simultaneously [12–13].

Section1.Heading: Materials and Methods
Section1.Para: In the present study, hematite iron ore fines and boiler grade coal are supplied by Vizag Steel, RINL, India. X-ray diffraction patterns of the samples have been analyzed by Rigaku Ultima-III machine, using Cu-Kα radiation in the range of 2θfrom 20 ° to 80 ° with a scan speed of 5 °/min, Wavelength Dispersive X-Ray Fluorescence (WDXRF) (MagiX2424, PANatytical Super Q), SEM (JEOL, model—JSM-5200) and EDX (Oxford Instruments). Other physical properties like density and average hardness have also been measured. The coal sample has been characterized by thermo-gravimetric (TG) analyzer (Perkin-Elmer model, Pyris diamond TG-DTA) in the range of 37 °C to 900 °C at the rate of 10 °C/min in N2 atmosphere and gas chromatograph (CHEMETO model no. 8610) analysis. A proximate analysis of coal [14] is also carried out, and the results are compared with the TG/DTA outcomes [15, 16]. To study the pyrolysis behavior, the coal is crushed and placed in the pyrolysis furnace. It is then heated to three different temperatures (550 °, 600 °, and 650 °C) for devolatilization. SYNGAS and carbon soot are generated by pyrolysis of coal. SYNGAS is characterized by Gas Chromatography (GC) [17, 18]. The carbon soot is collected and characterized by XRD and FESEM (Hitachi model S 4800). This gas mixture obtained by the pyrolysis of coal is used as a reductant for the reduction of iron oxides. The coal pyrolysis temperature is not sufficient for the reduction of iron oxide. Hence a vertical tube furnace is designed to transport the generated gas mixture to a higher temperature zone, where the reduction is feasible. Thermal gradient inside the vertical shaft tube furnace is measured to produce two different temperature zones from one heating element, leading to the better utilization of energy. Iron ore fines are subjected to sieve analysis to get different sizes of ore particles. Three ranges of size fractions are selected for briquetting: coarse (150 µm to 250 µm), semi-coarse (105 µm to 150 µm), and fine (63 µm to 105 µm). 4 % bentonite, 4 % molasses, and 2 % water are mixed with iron ore fines to make briquettes (particle size distribution of iron ore fines: coarse 25 %, semi-coarse 25 %, and fine 50 %). The mixture is placed in a die, and 330 kg pressure is applied to form the briquette. Briquettes are reduced in the furnace using the SYNGAS mixture. The reduced samples are then characterized by XRD and SEM/EDX. The chemical analysis of the reduced samples is performed by the standard procedure of the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS 10812:1992). In brief, a 0.2 g sample has been taken in a dry conical flask and a 100 ml freshly prepared ferric chloride solution (10 g in 100 ml distilled water) is added to it. Then it was stirred for 30 min. A prepared acid mixture (25 ml hydrochloric acid and 25 ml orthophosphoric acid) is added to the conical flask and cooled. After cooling, the solution is titrated against 0.1 N potassium dichromate solution using BDS indicator. The burette reading was then recorded and calculated to get the total metallic iron content of the reduced sample. The extents of reduction of reduced samples are calculated from mass loss (calculated in percentage as the ratio of actual mass loss [m1] to the mass loss in case of theoretically complete reduction [m2]). This is calculated on the basis of reweighing the sample after reaction. A theoretical calculation of mass loss for complete reduction is calculated beforehand, also taking account of other possible cases of mass loss (e.g. loss on ignition) to reduce their effect on final calculation. The ratio m1/m2, when calculated in percentage, gives an approximate quantitative idea about the extent to which the oxygen has been removed from the sample. It means that 100 % extent of reduction signifies a complete transformation from hematite to metallic iron.

Section2.Heading: Analysis of Iron Ore
Section2.Para: The wet chemical analysis of the supplied iron reveals the following:
The total elemental Fe and major oxide concentrations were measured using WDXRF. Table 1 shows the result of the analysis.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: WDXRF analysis of the raw iron ore (All values are in mass %)

Section3.Heading: Proximate Analysis
Section3.Para: The amounts of fixed carbon, moisture content, volatile matter, and ash content for the coal sample are calculated using the method of proximate analysis and are shown in Table 2.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Result of proximate analysis (All values are in mass %)

Section3.Para: Fig. 1 shows the TG/DTA plot of the boiler grade coal performed under nitrogen atmosphere. The graph shows a mass loss up to 110 °C, which has occurred due to evaporation of the moisture (7–8 %) from the coal.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: TG/DTA plot of the boiler grade coal (TG = Thermo Gravimetry, DTG = Derivative TG, DTA = Differential Thermal Analysis, DDTA = Derivative DTA)

Section3.Para: The major mass loss from 400 to 550 °C is due to the removal of the volatile matter (25–30 %). This is the single most important step during the devolatilization. The following mass loss occurred at a very slow rate, which might have occurred due to soot formation or slow oxidation by the trace amount of oxygen present in nitrogen. The derivative mass loss and derivative heat flow are also shown in Fig. 4. The mass loss around 375 °C may arise due to the burning of organic matters in the coal. The nature of the mass loss had confirmed the data received from proximate analysis.

Section2.Heading: Gas Chromatography Analysis
Section2.Para: The components of the gas mixture obtained by heating the coal at 650 °C are analyzed using GC. Fig. 2 is the GC plot which shows the presence of CO, CO2, H2, and CH4 in the gas mixture.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: GC analysis of boiler coal heated at 650 0C

Section2.Para: The percentage of each gas obtained by heating the coal at different temperatures is compared in Fig. 3. It is observed that the highest percentage of hydrogen in the reducing gas is obtained at 650 °C.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Comparison of the percentage of different gasses in the gas mixture obtained by pyrolysis of coal at different temperature

Section2.Heading: Analysis of Carbon Soot
Section2.Para: The carbon soot generated in the course of pyrolysis is analyzed using XRD and FESEM techniques. Fig. 4 shows the XRD plot of carbon soot which was obtained from the pyrolysis of boiler grade coal when heated at 650 °C. The plot does not show a sharp intensity peak for graphite. Instead, it shows a hump around 25 ° suggesting the presence of fine amorphous carbon in the pyrolysis product.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: XRD analysis of the carbon soot obtain by the pyrolysis of boiler grade coal at 650 0C showing the hump

Section2.Para: The FESEM image of the carbon soot is shown in Fig. 5. The images show agglomerated amorphous carbon particles. The size distribution of the particles is in nanometer range.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: FESEM analysis of the carbon soot at different magnifications ((a) and (b))

Section2.Heading: Furnace Design
Section2.Para: The furnace is designed for coal devolatilization with in-situ reduction facility to reduce iron ore briquettes using the SYNGAS and nano-sized carbon present in the soot generated by the pyrolysis of lean grade coal.

Section3.Heading: Design Requirements
Section3.Para: For the present work, only laboratory scale dimensions have been considered. To minimize the energy consumption, a single heating coil is used in such a way that, when the temperature at the hot zone (the reduction zone at the upper part of the furnace) is at 1200 °C, the temperature at the coal bed below the reduction zone reaches 550–650 °C. This implies that only the reduction zone will be heated up electrically and subsequently the coal bed will be heated up by the radiated heat from the reduction zone, eliminating the need of a second heating arrangement for pyrolysis. Therefore, the proper vertical distance between the reduction zone and the coal bed in the furnace shaft must be determined in order to find the correct location of the coal bed (where the temperature is 550–650 °C). So a temperature profile will exist in the furnace tube as a function of distance between the two zones. This thermal profile within the furnace is measured using a Pt/Rh thermocouple to get the correct distance between the reduction zone and coal bed. The temperature profile is shown in Fig. 6.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Temperature profile inside the furnace tube

Section3.Heading: Construction of the Furnace
Section3.Para: Fig. 7 shows the sectional view of the whole furnace. The exit gas port made of mild steel is placed on top of the furnace. The exit gas mixture released from the furnace comes out through this port. It is collected and analyzed by GC gas analyzer. The porous wire mesh is made of a high temperature oxidation resistant alloy (Inconel 600) and is placed inside the furnace tube at the hot zone. The mesh holds the iron ore briquettes for reduction. The wire mesh has been designed in a way that the reducing gas coming out of the coal-bed should react with the briquettes with best available contact area. The air-tight plug at the top of the tube maintains the reducing atmosphere inside the tube. The lid is made of refractory brick. Six silicon carbide (SiC) heating coils are used to maintain 1200 °C (maximum temperature limit) at the hot zone. A thyristor power device is used to maintain the slow increment of current using a current regulator. Thermocouples (Pt/Rh) are used to cheek the temperatures of the hot zones, where the wire mesh is placed as well as at the coal bed. The drop-bottom holds the coal and is made by refractory brick. The furnace stand is made up of mild steel and carries the total weight of the furnace.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Sectional view of the overall furnace

Section2.Heading: Treatment of the Samples
Section2.Para: The cylindrical briquettes have a fixed diameter of 25 mm, a height of approximately 5 mm, and a mass of around 10.5 g. Reduction is carried out by placing briquettes (three per experiment) on the wire mesh in one layer and keeping it at the reduction zone of the furnace where the temperature is around 1150 °C. The reduction time is set for 2 hours. The coal is devolatilized simultaneously as the bed under the wire mesh reaches the pyrolysis temperature (~ 600 °C). A new batch of coal is charged when the previous batch becomes fully charred. In each batch an average of 65 g coal is charged. This is the maximum amount of coal that the pyrolysis zone of the furnace can hold. The size fraction of charged coal is 6.3–19 mm. After complete pyrolysis, the charred coal is taken out by the drop-bottom (Fig. 7) and a new batch is put into the furnace. The coal is charged five times during the 2 hour span (at an average interval of 24 minutes). The furnace is heated up with the iron ore briquettes (kept at the wire mesh) up to 1150 °C under atmospheric conditions. As soon as the temperature of the coal bed reaches 550 °C by the radiated heat from the reduction zone, the first batch of coal is charged. The experiment is repeated for reproducibility eight times (excluding the start-up of the furnace).

Section3.Heading: XRD Analysis
Section3.Para: The X-Ray diffractogram (Fig. 8) shows the presence of Fe, FeO, and Fe3O4 phases as major peaks along with small amounts of Al2O3 and SiO2 (not shown in the picture), which is the gangue material already present in the ore. From the XRD analysis, it can be conjectured that the hematite phase followed its normal path of stepwise reduction from firstly magnetite, subsequently wüstite, and finally to metallic Fe.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Diffractogram of reduced sample showing metallic iron and reduced oxides

Section3.Heading: SEM/EDX Analysis of Reduced Sample
Section3.Para: Fig. 9 shows the SEM images of the briquettes reduced at 1150 °C for 2 hours (the image has been acquired from areas of the sample rich with metallic iron and does not represent the chemical composition of the whole sample). The images depict agglomerated metallic iron. Table 3 represents the mass percentage and atomic percentage of the elements in the sample before and after reduction.

A large decrease in the oxygen content as well as an increase in iron content are observed, compared to the EDX data of the sample before reduction. The XRD result, which indicates the stepwise reduction of the iron oxide briquette to metallic iron, could thereby be confirmed.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: SEM image of the briquettes reduced at 1150 0C for 2 hours at lower (a) and higher (b) magnifications (metallic iron region)
EDX data of the sample reduced at 1150 0C (Averaged, taken at metallic iron regions of the briquette)

Section2.Heading: Extent of Reduction, Metallic Iron Content, and Strength of the Reduced Sample
Section2.Para: The extent of reduction (see Section 2) of iron ore briquettes has been calculated and is 89.11 %. This value represents only the change in overall mass loss. The test for metallic iron of the reduced sample has been performed according to BIS 10812:1992, which reveals a metallic iron content of 59.91 %. The other parts of mass could therefore be considered to consist of oxides formed during intermediate steps as well as the gangue materials. Hence by performing the chemical analysis of the reduced sample, it is proved that the SYNGAS reduction process gives fruitful results using lean grade coal.

The reduced briquette resembles a very strong and stable agglomerated metallic aggregate. On shatter test, it demonstrates negligible loss of material due to impact, which would make it suitable for charging in a blast furnace.

ItemContent.Para: Iron ore briquettes were reduced successfully at 1150 °C using the pyrolysis products of lean grade coal in the laboratory scale. The pyrolysis of lean grade coal is carried out around 600–650 °C.
Amorphous carbon soot generated in the course of devolatilization of coal also helps in better reduction.
The vertical shaft furnace is designed in such a way that both reduction of ore and pyrolysis of coal can be carried out in the same furnace to make the process much more energy efficient.
The extent of reduction in the designed furnace using lean grade coal is approximately 89.11 % by weight loss method.

The metallic iron content of the reduced hematite sample is approximately 60 %. The chemical analysis of the reduced sample shows that the concerned reduction process provides a good degree of reduction.
In the actual process, these pre-reduced briquettes could be charged directly in blast furnace which in course will minimize the coke rate.
The development of a pilot plant is necessary for exploiting further industrial scopes of this process.
